body_html:
@asimshankar Thanks for the review. The PR has been updated. Currently, the implementation of this PR is to:

In case an UTF8 encoding is used, then either an empty string or a one character UTF8 (actually ASCII as there is only one char) is allowed to be specified as a delimiter. Properly encoding is validated now as well.

The reason for only allowing one char in UTF8 case is that, the StringSplit OP was defined such that only one char is allowed. If we expand the ops to take more than one chars, I think backward-compatibility may not be maintained.

For that it might make sense to introduce another OP instead of adding additional encoding attribute to StringSplit. I can update the PR if the other option is preferred. Please let me know.
body_text:
@asimshankar Thanks for the review. The PR has been updated. Currently, the implementation of this PR is to:
In case an UTF8 encoding is used, then either an empty string or a one character UTF8 (actually ASCII as there is only one char) is allowed to be specified as a delimiter. Properly encoding is validated now as well.
The reason for only allowing one char in UTF8 case is that, the StringSplit OP was defined such that only one char is allowed. If we expand the ops to take more than one chars, I think backward-compatibility may not be maintained.
For that it might make sense to introduce another OP instead of adding additional encoding attribute to StringSplit. I can update the PR if the other option is preferred. Please let me know.
body:
@asimshankar Thanks for the review. The PR has been updated. Currently, the implementation of this PR is to:

In case an UTF8 encoding is used, then either an empty string or a one character UTF8 (actually ASCII as there is only one char) is allowed to be specified as a delimiter. Properly encoding is validated now as well.

The reason for only allowing one char in UTF8 case is that, the `StringSplit` OP was defined such that only one char is allowed. If we expand the ops to take more than one chars, I think backward-compatibility may not be maintained.

For that it might make sense to introduce another OP instead of adding additional `encoding` attribute to `StringSplit`. I can update the PR if the other option is preferred. Please let me know.
